title: Conor McGregor reveals bottle of whiskey he gave to Vladimir had to be checked for POISON
text:
Conor McGregor claims Vladimir Putin checked there was no poision in the bottle of whiskey the UFC star gifted to the Russian president at the 2018 World Cup final.

McGregor said he gave Putin the first ever bottle produced of his own-brand Proper No. Twelve whiskey as France beat Croatia in Moscow, before the Russian president's security team sussed it out for poison.

The Irishman recently announced January 18 next year as the date of his next UFC clash in Las Vegas, with 'The Notorious' not having fought for over a year since his fourth-round submission defeat to Khabib Nurmagomedov.

Conor McGregor revealed how the whiskey he gave to Vladimir Putin was checked for poison

McGregor handed to Putin a bottle of his Proper No. 12 whiskey which has made £764m

The Notorious is set to return to UFC action on January 18 with the opponent as yet unnamed

This week, McGregor said of his encounter with the Russian president: 'President Putin's security detail is second to none as I'm sure you know.

'You don't mess around with Vladimir.

'So, I gifted the bottle, I gifted it to his security.

'They had to take the liquid from the bottle to make sure the liquid was safe and it was not maybe poisoned or what not and then it was gifted to Vladimir Putin.'

McGregor's founding of Proper No. 12 has helped him to become extremely rich

McGregor said he wasn't allowed to share a tipple with Putin because of security measures in place, but harboured hope the Russian president did treat himself to a sip.

'I'm sure he did have a taste and I'm sure he enjoyed it,' the controversial UFC star added.

McGregor launched Proper No. 12 in September 2018 and back in May he revealed the brand had already raked in an incredible £764million.

Forbes has estimated The Notorious to hold a personal wealth of more than £77m as he has established himself as one of the most recognised sportsmen in the world.

McGregor has called for a rematch against Nurmagomedov to settle a bitter score over their infamous 2018 battle, and the Irishman will be hoping his return to ring action in January can secure him some of the biggest, most lucrative fights available.
description: Conor McGregor (middle and right) has spoken about the bizarre time the bottle of whiskey he gave to Vladimir Putin (left) was removed by his security staff to check for poison.
